descriptions.high: You believe the state should play a strong role in both economic management and social transformation. You support government control of key industries, extensive welfare programs, and state intervention to reform traditional social practices.
descriptions.neutral: You hold balanced views on state intervention, supporting it in some areas while preferring limited government in others.
descriptions.low: You prefer minimal state intervention in both economy and society. You support market-based solutions, private enterprise, and preserving traditional autonomy in social and cultural matters.

descriptions.high: You strongly support group-based rights and protections. You favor affirmative action policies like reservations, minority rights, and state accommodation of diverse identities and communities.
descriptions.neutral: You hold moderate views on group recognition, balancing individual merit with some targeted support for disadvantaged communities.
descriptions.low: You lean toward majoritarian or individual merit-based approaches. You prefer uniform national identity over group-specific accommodations and may oppose special provisions for minorities.

descriptions.high: You favor universalist, rule-based distribution of resources. You believe government benefits should be allocated through objective criteria and transparent processes, without regard to identity or connections.
descriptions.neutral: You hold mixed views on distribution mechanisms, seeing value in both rule-based systems and community-based approaches.
descriptions.low: You accept or prefer particularist distribution based on identity networks and personal relationships. You believe politicians should prioritize their own communities and that personal connections are natural in governance.

distance.verySimilar: Very similar - you align closely on most issues
distance.moderate: Moderate alignment - you share some major positions
distance.significant: Significant differences - you differ on several key issues
distance.veryDifferent: Very different - you have contrasting positions on most issues

statism.similar: similar views on the role of the state
statism.youFavorMore: You favor {{more}}, while they lean toward {{less}}.
statism.youFavorLess: You favor {{less}}, while they lean toward {{more}}.

recognition.more: more support for group-based rights and protections
recognition.less: more emphasis on individual merit and uniform policies
recognition.youFavorMore: You favor {{more}}, while they lean toward {{less}}.
recognition.youFavorLess: You favor {{less}}, while they lean toward {{more}}.

sid.youFavorMore: You favor {{more}}, while they lean toward {{less}}.
sid.youFavorLess: You favor {{less}}, while they lean toward {{more}}.

veryHigh: Government healthcare expansion and universal coverage
Public sector growth in key industries
State control of natural resources and utilities
high: Mixed economy with strong state regulation
Labor protection laws and minimum wage policies
neutral: Mix of market forces and regulation
veryLow: Free market policies across all sectors
Voluntary community support over state welfare

veryHigh: Strong SC/ST/OBC reservation policies in education and jobs
Minority rights protections and special provisions
State recognition of multiple identity groups
high: Protection of linguistic and religious minorities
neutral: Balanced individual merit with targeted support
veryLow: Majoritarian policies and uniform national identity
No special provisions for minority groups

veryHigh: Rule-based transparent allocation of government benefits
Objective criteria for welfare schemes (income, need)
neutral: Mix of universal schemes and targeted programs
Some flexibility in distribution alongside rules
Balance between merit and community needs
low: Personal connections as part of governance
